title: Sprint 2: Mirror — Orientation
description: Before setting your Sprint 2 goals, read through each section below to learn what this sprint is about and how it works. Then answer the questions to confirm your understanding. Everything in Sprint 2 builds toward one outcome: proving you understood someone else deeply enough to create real value for them.

questions.infoBlock:
Sprint 2 Outcome

Demonstrate that you understood your classmate deeply enough to design something they couldn't have asked for themselves — with evidence that it addresses their actual need, not just their stated want.

The Big Shift: From Self to Partner

In Sprint 1, you were both the designer and the stakeholder. You had complete knowledge of your own problem — no interviews needed, no guessing about requirements.

Sprint 2 changes that fundamentally. You'll be paired with a classmate and you'll solve their problem, not yours. They become your stakeholder. You'll have incomplete knowledge and will need to communicate, listen, and adapt your design based on what you learn about their needs.

Your partner will be assigned to you before next week's class — please expect an email with your partner assignment.

Your partner will also be working on understanding your problem — it goes both ways. Every activity in Sprint 2 builds toward the outcome above: understanding someone else deeply enough to create something they couldn't have imagined on their own.
questions.prompt: What is the fundamental change in Sprint 2?
options: You work on a harder version of the same problem
You work with a partner — solving their problem, not yours
You switch from coding to design only
You work alone but on a problem assigned by the instructor
questions.hint: Think about who the 'stakeholder' is in Sprint 2 — whose problem are you solving?
questions.explanation: In Sprint 2, you'll be paired with a classmate. You'll solve their problem and they'll help you understand yours from a new perspective. The hardest part isn't building — it's truly understanding someone else's problem.

questions.infoBlock:
Why "Mirror"?

In Sprint 1, your design thinking was internal — only you needed to understand it. You knew your own friction, your own constraints, your own motivation.

In Sprint 2, you need to make all of that visible to someone else. Your documentation, your rationale, your communication — these become the interface through which your partner understands the problem.

Your partner is your mirror: they reflect back whether your thinking is actually clear or just clear to you. If they can't understand your problem from your description, the design will fail — no matter how good the code is.

This connects directly to the sprint outcome: to design something your partner couldn't have asked for themselves, you first need to understand them deeply enough that your thinking transcends their stated wants and reaches their actual needs.
options: You copy your partner's work
You make your thinking visible to your partner — what was internal becomes external
You reflect on Sprint 1 for the entire sprint
Your partner builds an identical version of your project
questions.hint: The sprint concept is 'Interface' — what stays internal vs. what becomes visible.
questions.explanation: In Sprint 1, your design thinking was internal — only you needed to understand it. In Sprint 2, you need to make your thinking visible to someone else through documentation, rationale, and communication. Your partner is your mirror, reflecting back whether you truly understand their problem.

questions.infoBlock:
How Sprint 2 Grading Works

Sprint 2 has four grading components:

  • Goals (20%) — Individual. Your personal sprint goals.
  • Reflections (20%) — Group-averaged. Both you and your partner contribute; the average score applies to both.
  • Check-ins (20%) — Group-averaged. Discovery documentation, design rationale, and feedback activities shared with your partner.
  • Demo (40%) — Individual. Your team-designed demonstration, judged by your partner.

This means 40% of your grade depends on mutual engagement. You need each other to succeed.

Notice how the grading structure maps to the sprint outcome: the group-averaged components (40%) build your deep understanding of your partner, and the Demo (40%) is where you prove that understanding produced something they couldn't have asked for themselves.
questions.prompt: Which parts of your Sprint 2 grade are group-averaged (meaning your partner's effort affects your grade)?
options: Goals and Demo
Reflections and Check-ins
Everything is individual
Everything is group-averaged
questions.hint: Goals (20%) and Demo (40%) are individual. What about the other 40%?
questions.explanation: Goals (20%) and Demo (40%) are individual. Reflections (20%) and Check-ins (20%) are group-averaged — your partner's participation matters. This creates mutual accountability: you need each other to succeed.

questions.infoBlock:
Two-Part Goal Setting

Unlike Sprint 1 where you set goals all at once, Sprint 2 splits goal setting into two parts:

  • Part I — Preparation (due Mon, Feb 16): Before you meet your partner. Reflect on your problem-solving skills, draft interview questions you'll use, and set a personal growth goal.
  • Part II — Partner Goals (due Thu, Feb 20): You'll work with your partner in class on Wednesday to complete this. Make sure to attend class to meet with your partner. Now that you know their actual problem, set specific goals for solving it.

This split exists because you can't set meaningful goals for solving someone's problem before you've met them. Part I prepares you; Part II grounds you in reality.

This directly serves the sprint outcome: you can't design something your partner couldn't have asked for themselves unless you first learn to ask the right questions (Part I) and then ground your goals in their actual situation (Part II).
questions.prompt: Why is Goal Setting split into Part I (before meeting your partner) and Part II (after meeting them)?
options: To give you more time to finish
Part I prepares you for the conversation; Part II sets real goals based on what you actually learned about your partner's problem
Part I is graded and Part II is optional
They cover different subjects entirely
questions.hint: You can't set specific goals for solving someone's problem if you haven't met them yet.
questions.explanation: Part I (due Feb 16) helps you prepare — reflecting on problem-solving skills and drafting interview questions. Part II (due Feb 20) happens after you meet your partner in class on Wednesday — now you can set specific goals based on their actual problem, not assumptions.

questions.infoBlock:
What Happens Each Week

  • Week 5: Meet your partner and start discovery — understand their problem deeply. Two-part Goal Setting, discovery documentation, and assumption audit.
  • Week 6: Design your demo — as a smaller class, you have more options than a written reflection. Each team will design their own demonstration goal: something that would genuinely impress a hiring manager. Continue deepening your understanding of your partner's domain.
  • Week 7: Build — create a prototype informed by what you've learned. Document your design rationale and get partner feedback.
  • Week 8: Team-Designed Demonstration — present your solution in the format your team designed. Your partner evaluates whether you truly understood their need.

questions.hint: Sprint 2 builds from discovery → demo design → building → demonstrating value.
questions.explanation: Sprint 2 follows a deliberate progression: meet your partner and begin discovery (Week 5), design your team's demo format and deepen domain learning (Week 6), build a prototype informed by their perspective (Week 7), then demonstrate your solution in the format your team designed (Week 8).

questions.prompt: The Sprint 2 outcome asks you to understand your classmate deeply enough to design something they couldn't have asked for themselves. What do you think will be hardest about reaching that level of understanding? What might get in the way?

questions.infoBlock:
The Sprint 2 Demo: Team-Designed Demonstration

In Sprint 1, you demonstrated your own growth to yourself through a written reflection. Sprint 2's demo is fundamentally different — and more ambitious.

Because this is a smaller class, you have more options than just writing and conversation. In Week 6, each team will design their own demonstration goal — something that would genuinely impress a hiring manager. Think beyond a standard presentation: live demos, interactive walkthroughs, before/after showcases, stakeholder interviews, whatever best proves you understood your partner's problem.

The bar is high: your partner — the person whose problem you solved — judges whether you truly understood their need. And the format you choose should make your human contribution visible: what did YOU bring that AI couldn't?

This is the sprint outcome in action: did you understand your classmate deeply enough to design something they couldn't have asked for themselves? Your team-designed demo is how you prove it.
questions.prompt: What makes the Sprint 2 demo different from Sprint 1's demo?
options: It's a longer written reflection
Each team designs their own demonstration format — something that would impress a hiring manager — and your partner judges the value
You present it to the instructor instead of a partner
It's about code quality rather than problem-solving
questions.hint: Think about who designs the demo format and who evaluates the result.
questions.explanation: Sprint 2's demo is team-designed: each team chooses a demonstration format that goes beyond standard written reflections. The goal is something that would impress a hiring manager while proving you truly understood your partner's problem. Your partner evaluates whether your solution addressed their actual need.

questions.placeholder: Consider: the challenge of understanding actual needs vs. stated wants, making your thinking visible, being evaluated by your partner, designing for someone else...

The student is reflecting on their readiness. Push them to be specific about WHAT excites or concerns them and WHY — especially in relation to the outcome. If they only focus on logistics (grades, deadlines, partner assignment), nudge them to think about the deeper challenge: truly understanding someone else's needs well enough to go beyond what they would ask for.
